q5.description: $\textbf {Definition}$: A complete GTG is a complete graph, meaning that every state has a transition to every other state. Any GTG can be converted to a complete GTG by adding edges labeled $\emptyset$ as needed.
q5.question: What is GTG
answer: A graph with edges labeled by Regular Expressions
choices: A graph with edges labeled by Regular Expressions

q6.description: $\textbf {Definition}$: A complete GTG is a complete graph, meaning that every state has a transition to every other state. Any GTG can be converted to a complete GTG by adding edges labeled $\emptyset$ as needed.
q6.question: How to convert any GTG to be complete GTG
q6.answer: Add all missing edges with $\emptyset$ labels
choices: Add all missing edges with $\emptyset$ labels

q7.question: What do we nean by L is regular
answer: L described by a regular expression
choices: L described by a regular expression

q8.description:
$\textbf {Proof}$:
$L$ is regular $\Rightarrow \exists$ NFA $M$ such that $L=L(M)$.
$\textbf {1}$ Assume $M$ has one final state, and $q_0 \not\in F$.
$\textbf {2}$ Convert $M$ to a complete GTG.
q8.question: How to convert any GTG to be complete GTG
q8.answer: Add all missing edges with $\emptyset$ labels
choices: Add all missing edges with $\emptyset$ labels

q9.description:
$\textbf {Proof}$:
$L$ is regular $\Rightarrow \exists$ NFA $M$ such that $L=L(M)$.
$\textbf {1}$ Assume $M$ has one final state, and $q_0 \not\in F$.
$\textbf {2}$ Convert $M$ to a complete GTG.
Let $r_{ij}$ stand for the label of the edge from $q_i$ to $q_j$
q9.question: What does $q_{ji}$ mean?

q11.description:
Then, the corresponding regular expression is:
$r=(r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*r_{ji})^∗r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*$
q11.question: Now, lets find how this RegEx created form the GTG on the left. Think about the first part of the RegEx: $(r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*r_{ji})^∗$. $r_{ii}^*$ means that, when the machine at the start state, it may loop Zero or more times to read Zero or more repeatition of $r_{ii}$

q12.description:
Then, the corresponding regular expression is:
$r=(r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*r_{ji})^∗r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*$
q12.question: Think about the first part of the RegEx: $(r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*r_{ji})^∗$. $r_{ij}^*$ means the machine then will move to state $qj$ by reading $r_{ij}$

q13.description:
Then, the corresponding regular expression is:
$r=(r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*r_{ji})^∗r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*$
q13.question: Think about the first part of the RegEx: $(r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*r_{ji})^∗$. $r_{jj}^*$ means that once the meachine is at $qj$ it may loop zero or more times to read zero or more occurance of $r_{jj}$

q14.description:
Then, the corresponding regular expression is:
$r=(r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*r_{ji})^∗r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*$
q14.question: Think about the first part of the RegEx: $(r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*r_{ji})^∗$. $r_{ji}^*$ means that the machine can go back to $qi$ by reading $r_{ji}$

q15.description:
Then, the corresponding regular expression is:
$r=(r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*r_{ji})^∗r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*$
q15.question: Think about the first part of the RegEx: $(r_{ii}^*r_{ij}r_{jj}^*r_{ji})^∗$. $($___$)^*$ means that the machine can repeate the previous part for zero or more times and end at $qi$

q18.description: Of course, we might have a machine with its start state also a final state. There are two ways to deal with this. One is to come up with a rule in this case. (Hint: Its the same rule, with an extra “OR” added for the case where we stay in the start state.) The other is to first convert our NFA to one with a single final state (separate from the start state).
q18.question: How can we convert an NFA to be with a single final state only
q18.answer: Create a new final state and connect all final states to it with $\lambda$ transitions
choices: Create a new final state and connect all final states to it with $\lambda$ transitions

q21.description:
Make the following replacements:
REPLACE
$r_{ii} \Rightarrow r_{ii}+r_{ik}r_{kk}^*r_{ki}$
q21.question: We made that replacement because $qi$ can go to itself by passing through $qk$. It will read $r_{ik}$ then looping in $qk$ to read zero or more $r_{kk}$ then moving back to $qi$ by reading $r_{ki}$

q22.description:
Make the following replacements:
REPLACE
$r_{ii} \Rightarrow r_{ii}+r_{ik}r_{kk}^*r_{ki}$
$r_{jj} \Rightarrow r_{jj}+r_{jk}r_{kk}^*r_{kj}$
q22.question: We made that new replacement because $qj$ can go to itself by passing through $qk$. It will read $r_{jk}$ then looping in $qk$ to read zero or more $r_{kk}$ then moving back to $qj$ by reading $r_{kj}$

q23.description:
Make the following replacements:
REPLACE
$r_{ii} \Rightarrow r_{ii}+r_{ik}r_{kk}^*r_{ki}$
$r_{jj} \Rightarrow r_{jj}+r_{jk}r_{kk}^*r_{kj}$
$r_{ij} \Rightarrow r_{ij}+r_{ik}r_{kk}^*k_{kj}$.
q23.question: We made that new replacement because $qi$ can go to state $qj$ by passing through $qk$. It will read $r_{ik}$ then looping in $qk$ to read zero or more $r_{kk}$ then moving to $qj$ by reading $r_{kj}$

q24.description:
Make the following replacements:
REPLACE
$r_{ii} \Rightarrow r_{ii}+r_{ik}r_{kk}^*r_{ki}$
$r_{jj} \Rightarrow r_{jj}+r_{jk}r_{kk}^*r_{kj}$
$r_{ij} \Rightarrow r_{ij}+r_{ik}r_{kk}^*k_{kj}$
$r_{ji} \Rightarrow r_{ji}+r_{jk}r_{kk}^*r_{ki}$
q24.question: We made that new replacement because $qj$ can go to state $qi$ by passing through $qk$. It will read $r_{jk}$ then looping in $qk$ to read zero or more $r_{kk}$ then moving to $qi$ by reading $r_{ki}$
